subject: Communication
title: The Empathy Gap: Hot and Cold States
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Empathy Gap: Hot and Cold States.

hook.text: 'I'd never yell at my kids.' Then you're exhausted, hungry, and stressed â€” and you yell. The empathy gap strikes again.

buildup.text: George Loewenstein's research: when we're in a 'cold' state (calm), we can't predict how we'll behave in a 'hot' state.

discovery.text: This gap works both ways. In a hot state, we can't imagine being calm.

twist.text: The empathy gap also affects how we judge others. Calm people can't understand why angry people 'just don't calm down.'

climax.text: Closing the empathy gap requires remembering your own hot states â€” using past experience to bridge to others' current.

punchline.text: Don't judge someone's fire from the comfort of your calm.

quiz.question: What is the hot-cold empathy gap?
options: Inability to predict behavior across emotional states
